title: Alex Angus
text:
Alexander "Alex" William Angus (11 November 1889 – 23 March 1947) was a Scottish international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> and cricket player.
Rugby Union career.
Amateur career.
He played club rugby for <a href="Watsonians%20RFC">Watsonians</a>.
Provincial career.
He played for <a href="Edinburgh%20District%20%28rugby%20union%29">Edinburgh District</a> against <a href="Glasgow%20District%20%28rugby%20union%29">Glasgow District</a> in the 1910 inter-city match. Edinburgh won the match 26–5, with Angus scoring a try.
He played for the <a href="Whites%20Trial">Whites Trial</a> side against the <a href="Blues%20Trial">Blues Trial</a> side on <a href="1910%E2%80%9311%20Scottish%20Districts%20season">21 January 1911</a>, while still with Watsonians. He scored a drop goal in a 26–19 win for the Whites.
International career.
He was capped eighteen for the rugby union team between 1909 and 1920.
Richard Bath mentions him as one of the three Scottish players "who've gone the longest without (between) scoring a try for Scotland" along with <a href="Alan%20Tait">Alan Tait</a> and <a href="Gary%20Armstrong%20%28rugby%29">Gary Armstrong</a>. This is partly because <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> occurred in the middle of his international career, a period in which all international rugby ceased. He was first capped in 1909, scoring two tries in fourteen matches before the Great War. His next four caps came in 1920, and he scored against on 28 February 1920 – just over nine years since his previous try. Scotland won that match 19–0.
Cricket career.
He also played for the <a href="Scotland%20national%20cricket%20team">Scotland national cricket team</a>.
